Feedback from the PTG: Please investigate what would it mean if we report the packet processing capacity per OVS bridge as an alternative.
Done

Feedback from the PTG: In case of OVS with vnic_type=normal it is OK to have a directionless resource as OVS in this case is CPU limited and that CPU is shared between directions. However in case of VOS with vnic_type=direct (e.g. when OVS is hardware offloaded) the different directions are handled by different hardware queues and therefore they have independent packet processing capacity. Therefore an OVS with offload should report a direction aware resource while the normal OVS should report a directionless resource. 

This also means that when the port has vnic_type=normal then the neutron should put the sum of the requested pps from the QoS rules to the resource_request as a directionless request. But when the vnic_type is direct then neutron should but the two QoS rules as two independent request towards the direction aware resource.
see the comment above about the OVS offload case

feedback from the PTG: feedback from the PTG: a basic form of data plane enforcement can be implemented by using the packet rate limiter QoS along with the min packet rate QoS rule. If the max_pps value is set to min_pps value and the every VM on the host has a min_pps (and therefore max_pps) defined then the max_pps data plane rules will implement a basic form of minimum guarantees as well.

feedback from PTG: We need to support deployments where the nova and the neutron controller services have different major versions. This means that both Wallaby Neutron - Xena Nova and Xena Neutron - Wallaby Nova situation needs to be handled. Therefore Xena Neutron should not automatically enable the new API extension that changes the format of the resource_request field as Wallaby Nova will not tolerate that.
Also Xena Nova should keep supporting the old resource_request format as Wallaby Neutron only sends that.

conceptual nit: I believe the resource_request is only disguised as a Neutron API. Logically it belongs to Nova. It's a request-response protocol where _Nova_ processes the request (either by itself or delegating parts of it to Placement). For example think about what would happen if multiple other OpenStack components/resources would want to add their resource_requests? Would you want them to each define their own resource request formats or would you want Nova to prescribe a resource_request format for all?

And yes, we had to piggyback the resource_request on some pre-existing Nova-Neutron communication channel. Because of that the resource_request field had to become part of the Neutron API too. But Neutron is only a server here as an HTTP-server, for the resource_request logically it's the other way around, Neutron is the client of Nova.
Thanks. Maybe this documentation will help avoid introducing even more custom formats.
Done

After talking to Bence:
* I will duplicate the final resource_request format in the nova spec to document it
* I will add a doc impact do document the resource_request in the nova developer doc

While I agree with your viewpoint I think Nova team does not enforce the one-true-resource-request format. See the resource request for a cyborg device: https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/accelerator/v2/index.html?expanded=get-one-device-profile-detail#get-one-device-profile

Also another point of view is that Neutron API is already providing all the necessary information (vnic_type, phynet name, qos policy and rules) that is needed for nova to figure out what resource are needed, but we decided to put the burden on neutron to re-frame this originally huma facing data to be a more machine readable data for Nova.

Anyhow other than agreeing with the sentiment I don't see what else I can do here in the spec.

nit: I believe it's a (planned) implementation detail that they will be allocated from different providers. In the request we only need to express that we _don't care_ whether they will be allocated from the same rp or not.

group policy is basically unusable we can never really set it to anything other then none

we need to replace it at some point with a way of expressing it between groups or just remove it entirely.

Good point. What we have to avoid here is to express that we want to have them allocated from the same provider. If we put them in the same group then we force placement to allocated them from the same provider. 

I've clarified this now.

When we put the resources into two separate groups then placement either let the groups overlap or strictly allocate them on different providers. Placement has a configuration knob on the GET /allocation_candidates API. The group_policy [1]. Unfortunately group_policy is a request global parameter (unlike same_subtree where you can define which groups needs to be in the same subtree) so Nova has to do some logic to figure out which group_policy value to use in the query. Today it is defaulted to None, so it allows overlapping. While the admin can override it via the flavor extra_spec to isolate all groups.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/placement/?expanded=list-allocation-candidates-detail#list-allocation-candidates
I agree.

At some point these objects may be re-used to support a resource_request coming from a 3rd (non Neutron) component (or for a different Neutron resource). In that case the object is only re-usable if it does not contain such assumptions. Overall Nova may have such assumptions, but because it knows _where_ the resource_request came from (here for example neutron/ports).

Yes. I think we already has the situation that request groups coming from cyborg has a different requester_id [1] while reusing the same RequestGroup object. So at least in the nova-placement interaction, where the groups from neutron and cyborg are mixed, the object works well. There is one networking specific connection though. The InstancePCIRequest.requester_id is also the port_uuid. And we use the RequestSpec.requester_id, which is today also the port_uuid, to look up a corresponding InstancePCIRequest in [2]. This needs to be changed.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/50fdbc752a9ca9c31488140ef2997ed59d861a41/nova/accelerator/cyborg.py#L62
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/50fdbc752a9ca9c31488140ef2997ed59d861a41/nova/compute/utils.py#L1512

not nessisarly.

of you take ovs it can proces somewhaare in the region of 1.6-2 mpps

it is more or less the same regardless of if you are usign 9k jumbo frames or 64byte packets.
the reasom for this is the bottlenek in packet porcessing is the matching and processign of the packet headers. not the copying of the packet data.

so if you nic bandwith is not not your botte neck for example if you use a 200G nic with kernel ovs and you vary the packet size between 64 and 9k the throughput will change liniarly with the size of the packets but provide your switch is not reaching line rate with your larges packet size reducing the packet size likely wont incease your througput.  the bottleneck is in clasifation and caluating how to forward the packet not in the data transfer.


so tl;dr the data processing rate in terms of pps is indepented of packet size provide we are not reaching the bandwith limits or our phsyical interface. so in generally we can ignore packet size in the scenario.

this assumption works, but then we tie our switch resource capacity on a specific assumption which could change later, meaning we'd have to reshape existing allocations.

By design, I think we should tell that the inventories of those resource classes should be related to an OVS, not an agent (even if that means creating a child RP just for this)

You have a point. Technically neutron can report a new RP under the agent RP that represents the OVS instance itself. This would mean that the OVS bridge RPs that are under the agent RP today also needs to be moved under the new OVS instance RP. That is possible to do via re-parenting when that is supported in Placement via: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova-specs/+/788243 

Would be nice to see other reviewer's view on this change.

Adding an OVS RP
Pros:
* better modelling reality (the pps resource is provided by the OVS instance not the agent)
* possible more future proof if we ever support more than one OVS per agent
Cons:
* we need to do re-parenting now which is an extra dependency on a new placement feature
* YAGNI

The format of the resource_request needs to change to accommodate the case when both pps and bandwidth is requested for the same port. Therefore we need a list. When only bandwidth or only pps is requested we still use the same format, a list, but it will only have a single request group in that list. 

So in short, yes the format of the resource_request will change for the case when only bandwidth is requested. The meaning of the request will not change.

well, sec. How an end user can know that if their want to provide a pps query for a port, this would or wouldn't work, then ? Would they get some exception when defining the port if the neutron port isn't OVS backed ?

Mostly via documentation and via the admin who creates the QoS policies for the end user.

Similarly, today nothing prevents you to request bandwidth in a cloud that does not have bandwidth inventory. Or nothing prevents you to request VGPU even if there is no VGPU inventory. It will result in a NoValidHost during scheduling. 

Similarly nova does not prevent you to create a flavor that will never fit to any existing compute in the system. 

If you create a QoS policy with pps, and then attach that to a neutron port with vnic_type=direct-physical (the only vnic type OVS does not support today if so configured) then the boot with that port will result in placement returning zero allocation candidates.

cinder/volume/drivers/infinidat.py.message: OK, so the problem is that train can run under either py2 or py3.  In py2, you have to use the third-party mock library, but in py3 we use mock from the unittest standard library.  So, this change will work when running under py3, but if you run this under py2, we will have the problem that the mock library may not be available because it's not in requirements.txt.  So I think when run under py2, you will see the issue that made you notice this in the first place unless you make the change I suggest in setup.cfg.

Do we really want to change the requirements on a stable branch?

Honestly, I'm not even sure people are using this driver, at least in train. It's broken and wouldn't work in the current state anyways, unless operators manually installed mock. What were doing here is basically trying to fix it for everyone, otherwise we fallback on original behavior. This worked for my environment built on RHOSP and it looks like it works for the CI as well.

The reason why I want this fixed is because it breaks oslo-config-validator.
Understood, but I am against merging a change into train that doesn't solve the issue for both python 2 and python 3.  Willing to listen to the opinions of other stable cores, though.

I agree with you that, ideally, we'd fix everything and completely remove the mock from production code, but I'm in no position to do this without having to deepdive and, again ideally, have access to an infinidat storage controller. While this is addressed, we end up with broken tools like oslo-config-(generator|validator).

I believe that this patch will address the collateral damage that mock is causing without breaking anything else and falling back on the original behavior if required.

ceph-rgw/values.yaml.message:
so what happens if someone set "delete: true" but left it there unattended, would that cause any problem for subsequent deployment?  I just worry this introduces some unintended headache.
Maybe instead of doing it this way, add a new section for "delete_placement_targets" and list them out explicitly perhaps?   so only the ones listed will be deleted, and if they don't exist, the code can just skip the deletion attempt?
That's fair.  I was most concerned if by accidentally leaving "delete: true" would cause problem subsequently, and your explanation addressed my concern.

The current design is that "delete: true" deletes the placement target after it is created if it didn't exist previously. So in the case of a clean deployment or a deployment subsequent to a prior delete, the placement target would get created and immediately deleted, which achieves the target state. Once an existing placement target has been deleted it can be removed from the manifest completely, including its "delete" key, in order to avoid re-creating and deleting the placement target on subsequent deployments.

Adding a "delete_placement_targets" section would present the same challenges in the case where the placement target definition wasn't removed when the delete was added. Deletes would naturally have to happen after creates to account for this, and a placement target specified in both places would get created and then deleted, which is the same behavior as the current implementation. It would provide an optimization in one case do to it that way, but there wouldn't be any logical difference.

The same optimization could also be made by adding a condition to the if statement on line 55 of the script to skip creation of the placement target if it is being deleted. Delete is already skipped if the placement target doesn't exist. This would also keep management of a placement target to a single section in the yaml. Would this be an acceptable solution?

pkg/services/jumphost.go.message: By default kubernetes should already check if the container process is started and not crashed, so i don't think we need to check that. A tcp check though would additionally ensure that the process is responding to traffic.

I think since the entrypoint starts the service but then just runs an infinite loop to stay alive, it won't crash if sshd stops because it never checks status again and the loop will just keep running. This behavior was confirmed by removing both probes and killing sshd in the jumphost container--the container never restarted and sshd remained down indefinitely.

I'm thinking it might make sense to move the service status check inside the loop in entrypoint.sh so the container will actually crash if sshd dies, and then implement the TCP checks as the liveness / readiness probes. Does this seem reasonable?

nit: slight preference to use a named port so that the port number is only specified in one place:
https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-liveness-readiness-startup-probes/#use-a-named-port

Totally agree, but I ran into some strange behavior when I used the named "ssh" port, so I fell back to using the port number instead. The "ssh" string value was being evaluated as 0 and validation would fail because it was outside the valid integer port range.

I'm not sure I understand the root cause yet, but I found something in the Cloud Run documentation[0] that seems to indicate this is a known issue with the IntOrString type in this context.

[0] - https://cloud.google.com/run/docs/reference/rpc/k8s.io.api.core.v1#k8s.io.api.core.v1.TCPSocketAction

Haha, right after I posted this, I decided to try with the instr.FromString function rather than populating the IntOrString struct directly, and now it works just fine using a named port. Not sure what's different. But I'll push up a new PS using the named port since that's the better approach.

swift/container/backend.py.message:
I did have a query that gave us the next upper and the count in the one SQL by doign a sub command... probably end up being just as costly as 2 seperate calls I guess.

Here it is:

select count(name) as obj_count, max(name) as upper from (select name from object where name > <last_upper> order by name LIMIT <shard_size>);

Which looks like:

QUERY PLAN
|--CO-ROUTINE 1
|  |--SCAN TABLE object USING COVERING INDEX ix_object_deleted_name
|  `--USE TEMP B-TREE FOR ORDER BY
`--SCAN SUBQUERY 1

And returns a row (500k, <next_upper>)

When it gets to the end it'll be (200k, <last obj in DB>) so if obj_count in the result < shard_size we return upper as None.

But no idea which would be faster. Depends on the speed of the second SCAN SUBQUERY. And seems if doing a CO-ROUTINE we need a temp b-tree because when I run it on yours:

QUERY PLAN
`--SEARCH TABLE object USING COVERING INDEX ix_object_deleted_name (deleted=? AND name>?)

QUERY PLAN
`--SEARCH TABLE object USING COVERING INDEX ix_object_deleted_name (deleted=? AND name>?)

First for the upper then for the count.. although we know from experience (unless it was fixed in sqlite) the offset walk can be expensive even though it doesn't say it here. But so might the LIMIT (never looked into that one).

swift/cli/manage_shard_ranges.py.message:
hmmm, so there is no way to choose auto but also specify the 'target' number of rows per shard. That seems a bit of a backwards step if you have previously been using something other than shard_container_threshold // 2 but want to benefit from the new 'avoid tiny tail shard' feature :( (Also complicates testing)

I tried to find a workaround, but it'll end up needing to pass shard_container_threshold to find_ranges, which feels wrong, so I ended up thinking that maybe we need '--minimum-shard-size' instead of 'auto'. That kills 2 birds with one stone:

- can still specify rows_per_shard
- avoids needing to hard code in the size at which the final shard is considered too small

It's kinda why the initial version of the in broker fix small ends wasn't triggered and just had it turned on permanately. Just always fix the bug even if it diddles with the last 2 shard counts, when we have a tiny one at the end we do anyway, it oviously isn't the shard_size and just permanately fixed the problem.

But then that changed the behaviour of what current people may expect so tied it into auto.

swift/container/backend.py.message:
We could just as easily grab the number of objs_left here and calculate, but was trying to avoid a count(name) on every _get_next_shard_range_upper and only leave it when we're at the end of the scanning.

But maybe finding the next upper, as it also hits the index, is just as expensive as the count.
or (see comment in first patch in chain) just find out if there are more than some threshold of objects left, without needing the exact count.

True, but we're only getting rows_left if there if we've hit then with second_upper so we know the max number of rows is 2 x shard_size - 1. So hoping the index here will help. So it's not like we're attempting to get a large list. Further I assume the index is some kind of efficient tree like structure. firing next uppers to determine how much is left might would be the same or extra db work on the index I suspect.

I wonder if we could instead do something like:

  select count(name) as obj_count, max(name) as upper from (select name from object where name > <last_upper> order by name LIMIT <shard_size>);

Which will return the obj_count and the next upper. We will be returning all the rows too in the sub query, but might assume sqlite is smart about what it actually loads there. A sample on one of my SAIOs:

 sqlite> select count(name) as obj_count, max(name) as upper from (select name from object where name > 'beta029' order by name LIMIT 5);
5|beta034

Where the records in the question are:

sqlite> select name from object where name > 'beta029' order by name LIMIT 5;
beta030
beta031
beta032
beta033
beta034

And the query plan is:

sqlite>  explain query plan select count(name) as obj_count, max(name) as upper from (select name from object where name > 'beta029' order by name LIMIT 5);
QUERY PLAN
|--CO-ROUTINE 1
|  |--SCAN TABLE object USING COVERING INDEX ix_object_deleted_name
|  `--USE TEMP B-TREE FOR ORDER BY
`--SCAN SUBQUERY 1


If I do the same at the end of the list I get:

`--SCAN SUBQUERY 1
sqlite> select name from object where name > 'beta047' order by name LIMIT 5;
beta048
beta049
sqlite> select count(name) as obj_count, max(name) as upper from (select name from object where name > 'beta047' order by name LIMIT 5);
2|beta049

So would have to be careful about how we end, it wont be a None anymore. So if we happen to have the perfect amount of rows for the last shardrange we need to make sure we do look ahead. But that should be covered right always looking 2 ahead.

we're throwing away the work that was done to find second_upper when it is not None...

I'm imagining we could have a method something like:

  def _get_next_two_uppers(last_upper, shard_size):
      # returns a tuple of tuple of next two (uppers, counts):
      #   ((name1, shard_size), (name2, shard_size)) -> found two uppers and there's more to come
      #   ((name1, shard_size), (None, count<shard_size)) - found penultimate and final shards: caller can decide what to do
      #   ((None, count<shard_size), (None, None)) - found final shard: caller can decide what to do

or maybe it would be better as a generator that yields (shard upper, count) for the caller to build a list?

  def yield_uppers(last_upper, shard_size, limit):
      # yield (upper, count) starting after last_upper until limit
      # or until upper=None
maybe I should've put the above comment SQL statement stuff here, opps
Haven't looked into just storing the object_count value and then checking again to see how much it's changed yet.
often (all but penultimate range) we make a query to find second_upper but then don't use it, so the same query will be repeated on the next call
yeah, that is a downside to this approach 😞

if we want to make this configurable there will be a lot of plumbing to do - I wonder if we can have this function return the raw data (upper, object count) and tidy up the tail further up the call chain
Yeah, I guess we could do this all up the call chain and just leave some simpler helper methods. Like this origianly was.

I tried to work out how to avoid doing the extra work in _get_next_shard_range_upper (i.e. always doing the second_upper query). Ideally we would only do extra work when we find the last shard range, and then maybe merge it into the penultimate. But that is difficult given the way limit is used, meaning that the current call to find_shard_ranges may only find the last shard range and it's too late to merge into the penultimate.

So..I ended up moving the 'merge last into penultimate' to the callers of this function and leaving this function to just find uppers and object counts. Then we can do less work here and make decision about the last shard range in a place where we have all the shard ranges.
how does this interact with correct_tail?
oh, we're already making a guesstimate of the final shard object count! Could we already have been avoiding small shards using this value??

yeah maybe we could! Maybe past us wasn't so silly we just didn't complete the thought process.

If this is small enough we should just update the last to range to be upper = ''. However, as you mentioned the limit becomes a PITA.

just a thought.. maybe order is incorrect...
Does this fall into the category of things we expect to be configured on the disk image ahead of time, as opposed to reconfigured during a deployment?
Perfect, thanks - I think making the assumption that the config won't change (without a host redeployment at least) is a reasonable assumption to start with.

If the config.toml will not change over the time, we should add it to the disk image. The reconfiguration of config.toml is necessary when we are switching over from docker to containerd. If we doing the deployment with containerd as default CRI from scratch, we shouldn't reconfigure anything and can just add the file to the disk image.
There's no harm in leaving docker enabled, is there?  There may be non-kubernetes (maybe operational) activities that may want to use it?

I see.  We don't add proxy settings to the docker unit file today, is that just a gap?

I think the setup I'd suggest is:
1) don't even reference docker in here at all -- if it's on the disk image and running, that's fine; if not, that's fine
2) shift responsibility to configuring docker proxy to the end user, rather than caring for it here (in a place where we don't even need to use docker).  I.e., the user could configure the proxy information in their base image

Basically -- ignore docker here because we don't use it :)  Let me know if I'm overlooking something!
Yes, we can leave docker enabled and even running (both cases are tested). The only one thing: if we do so, we have to add proxy settings to the unit file, and restart the service.

I think a better way that I can phrase it is:  we do care about whether or not docker is installed and running, but the right place to address that (one way or the other) is in the disk image that gets deployed (which will also be operator specific).  One operator might choose to remove docker entirely with performance in mind, and another might want to leave it installed for operational purposes.  Either way, I'm thinking the best place to encode that is in their image, rather than caring for it here during the (unrelated) task of kubernetes setup.

Thanks Matt! I have two concerns about docker:

1. If we have it enabled and running, we wasting some resources, like RAM and CPU. Not critical, but what for?
2. It could be confusing for a systems administrator, when he sees docker running. There are just few signs, what service is a default CRI - docker or containerd. In fact, we should do kubectl describe node to find things out.

All of the above - is my motivation to implement docker things as I did. However, I agree, that we can "blindly" forget about docker. If you don't mind about resource consumption, I'll fix the configuration the way you suggested. Please let me know.

these could all be a single task btw.

But this facts are dependent one on the other. If they are set up in the same task, the second would find the first undefined. And the third would find the second undefined. So in this case, defining the facts in a single task will not work.

command: |

This is a complicated topic. And both directions have issues. 

Automatically triggering migration is confusing for the user. So if we go that direction then I would suggest to extend the migration / resize / live migration API to specify the new group instead. This would allow moving servers between groups as well. Also this way the heavy operation is more explicitly visible to the user and the API policy is applied from the more expensive operation perspective.

If we go with the check-the-policy-at-group-change-and-reject-if-it-is-not-already -fulfilled direction, then we have a problem of pre-creating a situation where the VM is already in a good place so that it can be added to the group. 

Also please note that special care needs to be taken as a server can only be part of 0 or 1 server group at a time.

the 'force' option will become confuse after the action. the user doesn't know whether the instance match the affinity. and no way to correct that.

more prefer to extending the migration API.

removing a server form a group should never resolt in moving the vm regardless of what we do on adding a server to a group.

so you shoudl remove this
yes 400 or 409 are both ok in this case.

if we were to implement this and have the implict move operation i think it should be project_admin
not admin or owner

Should this be an image property?  If so, should there be something similar for the hypervisor capabilities as well?

Yes, it should be an image property, since not all the guests support this feature. As for the hypervisor capabilities, that might be an interesting idea, but cannot be done at the moment. 

I've came across something similar in the past, Hyper-V Generation 2 VMs, which could have been solved via hypervisor capabilities (hosts would post which generations it supported), but ultimately, it was solved by specifying the image property hypervisor_version_requires. This solution can also be used in this case.
Could this be a configurable option vs. a hard assumption?  e.g., specified via a hypervisor capability?

Hard assumption for now. This blueprint is currently for upsizing, as downsizing can be a little bit more problematic. For example, you won't be able to downsize the memory from 8gb to 4gb if the guest is currently using 6gb.

For the time being, if this blueprint will be accepted, upsizing will be prioritary for Liberty, and if the time allows it, downsize as well.
Ditto on the configurable option.
Ditto as well. Also, downsizing the number of VCPUs is even more problematic than downsizing the memory, since the guest will have to know to evacuate the processes in the vcpus that will be removed.
Should this be a hypervisor capability vs. a nova.conf option?  Then the respective drivers could apply whatever logic (e.g., version checking) they want and set the capabilities accordingly.

I am given to understand that some operators wouldn't want this feature at all and they would disable it anyways (via policy.json).

You have an interesting point, IMO, this should be reported via hypervisor capabilities, but currently, there is no way to expose those capabilities. 

Speaking of which, this makes me think about Phase II of this blueprint, as the scheduler does not know if the new host supports live resize or not, it can cause live resize to fail.

This can be solved via the hypervisor_version_requires I've mentioned above, as it will be used by the scheduler.

See above--can't we just make live resize and the various vcpu+up/down, memory+up/down, disk+up/down, etc. all various capabilities the hypervisors publish and then the upper layers can be purely data driven?  Just a thought.

For now, the focus of this blueprint will be live resize up.

IMO, the most possible resource for live downsize would be memory, as stated above.

For disk, the typical usecase I'm thinking about is that you can run out of storage at one point, so you will perform a disk live resize and fill the disk further. Downsize won't be possible, as the actual disk size will be bigger than the new flavor disk size. To make things even more difficult, the extra storage will also be used by the partition tables inside the guest, so truncating that could cause data loss. Plus, AFAIK, there is no way to tell the cloud-init agent to shrink the partition to the desired size.

As for vCPUs, see above.

Just curious how this will interface with the nova-scheduler to ensure it doesn't try to assign another host?  Are you planning on passing 'force_hosts' to the scheduler when 'live resize' is passed?  Some other alternative?

I'm sure you know this, but the reason I ask is because that allow_resize_to_same_host = True doesn't guarantee the VM's current host will be selected (it's just not auto-excluded).

Will look into that.

But for now, I was thinking that it would use the same notifications as cold migration.

As I mentioned previously, it seems that it would be more appropriate to use a hypervisor capability than a nova.conf option for this as the virt drivers can just perform this logic automatically and save operators the time of managing more conf options... unless I'm overlooking something?

Image property hypervisor_version_requires should be used.

And as I mentioned, this also seems appropriate as a hypervisor option too.

specs/newton/approved/instance-live-resi.message:
It feels like some people will turn this off with policy.

Phase II might be different.

If we can reserve a certain amount of resources for an instance's live-resize (let's say 2X, specified through flavor extra_specs), we can ensure that the live-resize won't fail because there weren't enough resources for live-resize.

I think we need to add some extra metadata to the flavours to control whether / how resize is allowed.

In particular for KVM, at the time you boot the guest initially you need to be able to say what maximum possible memory and vcpus you might want to use in the future.

ie, if you start with a flavour with 2 GB of RAM and want to be able to resize, you need to tell KVM at boot time to reserve memory mappings / slots to allow say 16 GB of RAM.

So against the original flavour we boot the guest from, we need to record at least  'max_memory' and 'max_vcpus' values.

This would serve as a useful access control mechanism for the cloud administrator.

if neither max_memory or max_vcpus are set, then any resizing of ram/cpus would be entirely forbidden.  If max_memory and max_vcpus were set, then you could you could resize *only* to target flavours whose memory/vcpus are less than or equal to the original flavour's max_memory/max_vcpus.

This allows the cloud admin to configure some flavour which permit resizing and some flavour which do not permit it.

It would also open the door to future ability to pre-reserve extra resources on the original host. ie when booting the guest with 2 GB of RAM and max_memory 4 GB, it could take a soft claim on the extra 2 GB of RAM, so that it is more likely available should a resize be needed later. Such an ability to pre-reserve resources could be toggled by another flavour extra spec property.

As an alternative to storing the original flavor against the instance, we can specify that when live-resize an instance, we ensure the max vcpu/memory values in the new flavor, if present, are less than or equal to values of the current flavor and as you have specified, whenever the max vcpu/memory values are not present, live-resize is disabled. 

This way, live-resize limits always conform to the values specified in the current flavor without the need to store original flavor in the instance. 

So really we have the following possible scenarios:
(1) Current flavor has no max values defined --> live-resize disabled.
(2) Current flavor max values >= New flavor max values --> live-resize is allowed and the subsequent live-resize operation will conform to limits defined in the new flavor.
(3) Current flavor max values <= New flavor max values --> live-resize disallowed.  
(4) Current flavor max values defined and max values not present in new flavor --> live-resize is allowed but subsequent live-resize shall be disabled.

This behavior will always conform to the invariant that live-resize always follow whatever is defined in the flavor(instance-type).

One catch here is that the guest will retain the original max values set during reboot. But this should not impact the behavior of live-resize as we will always check live-resize targets against the current flavor's max values, which are always guaranteed to be less or equal to original values (or not present at all).
Yes, good point. When we boot the image we keep a copy of the flavour against the instance, so we just need to make sure we don't ever overwrite this fields.

Seems valid in my opinion and more feasible. It will also make libvirt more happy. The pre-reserve extra resources sounds like a good idea as well.

One thing that should be kept in mind, is that we don't lose those original max_vcpus and max_memory values, otherwise this mechanism would be exploitable.

For example, having the original flavor m1.tiny with the extra_spec max_memory=16GB, the new flavor m2.tiny should not have max_memory=32GB, otherwise we can get to 32 GB from 2 live-resizes, even though it wasn't intended to be possible.

There needs to be much more detailed added to this, especially around interactions with various different ways VMs can be configured - eg NUMA, cpu pinning, huge pages, and more. For example, if 1GB huge pages are used, that restricts what possible memory sizes you can resize to - ie you can't resize to 2.5 GB of RAM. With NUMA, if the new flavour specifies a different NUMA topology from the old flavour you can't neccesarily change this on the fly in the guest.

There also needs to be detail about error handling & reporting behaviour. ie if you resize vcpus, and then try to resize memory and fail what happens. Do you pretend success even though some things failed or report failure, even though some things succeeded, or try to rollback things which succeeeded, even though rollback may also then fail or even be imposible.

1. I think if the resize is requested for mulpiple resources in one request and one of them failed the fulfilling of the request failed = full failure. If the request is for one resource type - that's easy then.

2. Should we actually try to the 'most problematic/not downsizable' resources first as it would make the least number of resources needed to be rolled back in case of failure?

3. Additionally I think, i.e. for vcpus, there may be a way of enabling the new set of cpus but not yet letting kernel scheduler to consider it - it would be a sort of way to test the upsize with an easier downsize process.

True, but for the moment, I am only targeting the already mentioned resources from the beginning: cpus, memory, and local disk; meaning that live-resizing to a new NUMA topology won't be allowed.

Ofcourse, in the future of this feature, we are going to add support for live-resize for NUMA topologies, PCI hot-plugging, etc.

As for error handling in case of partial-success / partial-failure, that is a valid point and we should find a way to handle this properly. Rollback would basically also mean supporting live down-size, which is a bit outside the scope of this blueprint. I am going to investigate how each hypervisor handles this sort of errors and if they support down-size (if they do, we might attempt a graceful rollback, if possible).

I am expecting down-size to be less supported than up-size (meaning that, if vcpu up-size is supported, vcpu down-size might not). In this case, It would be better to live-resize resources that can't be rolledback last.

If rollback fails, the instance's flavor will have to be updated to reflect the current state of the VM. What to do with the instance after this, I don't know at this moment.

One way to avoid such complex questions and problems, would be to enforce live-resize for only one resource type at a time. It is tedious, and a bit inconvenient, but a lot safer.

The online resize feature is depended on Guest OS. IMO, please add below matrix for clarifying which guest OS support online resize.


+----------+----------------+------------+--------+--------+
|          |      Disk      |   Memory   | VCPUs  |  PCIs  |
+==========+================+============+========+========+
| CentOS   | ✓              | ✓          | ✓      | ✓     |
+----------+----------------+------------+--------+--------+
| SUSE     | ✓              | ✓          | X      | ✓     |
+----------+----------------+------------+--------+--------+
| Ubuntu   | ✓              | ✓          | ✓      | ✓     |
+----------+----------------+------------+--------+--------+
| Windows  | ✓              | ✓          | ✓      | ✓     |
+----------+----------------+------------+--------+--------+

References:
1. http://www.cyberciti.biz/faq/debian-rhel-centos-redhat-suse-hotplug-cpu/

1. We're going to assume that we can't live-resize at all.

2. That's actually an interesting question. AFAIK, whenever image metadata properties are used, they're fetched directly from glance and converted to the ImageMetaProps object, which means that an instance could be spawned without the os_live_resize image metadata property, but afterwards the image metadata property could be added, and it would be taken into account (95% sure it happens like this). But I'm more skeptic about boot-from-volume instances. Initially, the cinder volume will inherit the glance image's metadata properties, but I highly doubt that they're going to be updated / added when the respective glance image properties get updated / added / removed. I this case, I think that the os_live_resize metadata property will have to be added / updated on the cinder boot volumes as well.

I will have to look into 2. But if anyone already knows the answer, I'd greatly appreciate it. :)

And unrelated to live-resize, now that you've mentioned 2., this could potentially be a problem on cold resize / cold migration. Generally, image metadata properties are important to the instances themselves, and in some cases, mandatory.

For example, a Hyper-V Generation 2 VM disk can only be used by a Hyper-V Generation 2 VM, and a Gen 1 VM disk can only be used by a Hyper-V Gen 1 VM. So if I'm creating a Hyper-V Generation 2 VM instance (has the image metadata property hw_machine_type=hyperv-gen2), and afterwards I decide to delete that image property, and then decide to cold migrate / cold resize the instance, I'd end up with a broken instance, because most drivers on cold migration / resize destroy the instance on the source and recreate it at the destination. But since the image property no longer exists, a Generation 1 VM is created instead, and it won't be able to boot a Generation 2 VM disk.

Hm, well, at the time of writing this spec, the only options were image metadata properties and flavor extra-specs. There's already a very large number of flavors extra-specs which leads to a large and hard to manage number of flavors. Additionally, if an instance was spawned without live-resize related extra-specs, it would have to be cold-resized to a flavor containing them in the first place, while this is not a problem for image metadata properties. If there's a new, better way to set this properties, I'm open to it.

As for **why** we actually need this, IMO, there are 2 issues:

1. Not all users know or have to know what resources are live-resizable on an OS. For example, older OSes might not support memory / CPU live-resize. Additionally, there were discussions to extend this resource list to include NUMA-related resources in the future. IMO, the operators should set this property on images, the users will only care if they can live-resize an isntance or not.

2. Implementation-wise. We need to know what live-resizable resources are supported by the guest. If we live-resize the number of CPUs / memory, but the guest is not consuming those resources, then we're pointlessly claiming resources for an instance that should but does not consume them.
I think this should be "os:max_memory.N" and "os:max_vcpus.N"

Would splitting the check out into nova-status be worthwhile?

Wouldn't this also be listed under the placement sub command?

> Would splitting the check out into nova-status be worthwhile?

That's a very good idea but unfortunately, we need to have a command that should be run in the compute services, while the nova-status command is run in the controller.

I appreciate that you're working to the current constraints imposed on us by TripleO's interpretation of FFU but this makes me think it's time to reset these given our needs in Nova.

We could mandate the need to have Keystone and Placement available during each version step of the upgrade to simplify this down to a single command on each compute.

This would mean that the control plane and compute plane upgrades would be tied together but I think that would be the case with either approach.

Otherwise we are asking the operator and/or upgrade deployment tooling to orchestrate multiple steps for each compute in an environment, that just isn't going to scale well.

Thoughts?

Yeah sorry I appreciate that, just without it this is going to be a rather large task to automate either for operators or deployment tools orchestrating an upgrade.

On that, did you run this proposal past the any deployment tools upstream (TripleO, Kolla, OSA, JuJu?) and if not would you mind bringing it up on the mailing list?

Either way this is going to have an impact on the framework of the upgrade and they will need to buy into this before we can commit in Nova IMHO.

I must also say that I would rather this approach. The lockstep pattern proposed seems even more difficult and error prone than simply starting those two (mostly dependency free) services. We should definitely bring this up on the ML first

What is old and new PMEM device here? During confirm_resize you should not do any expensive operation. At that point the VM should already be fully migrated to the dest host and actually running there.

there is no such thing that nova unconfirming a migration. When a cold migration / resize is initiated by the user then,
1) nova stops the VM on the source compute
2) nova moves all the VM data from the source to the dest compute.
3) then nova starts the VM on the dest comute. At this point the VM is moved to verify_resize state
4) end user needs to decide to either confirm or revert the migration. (e.g. the end user might check that the VM is running well before it decides)
5a) if the user confirms the resize / migration then nova needs to clean up the VMs data on the source compute
5b) if the user reverts the resize / migration then nova needs to stop the VM on the dest compute and clean up the dest compute, and start the VM on the source compute

you have to move the PMEM data at step #2) so that at step #3) the VM can be started up on the dest compute.

I think this is a big problem as we have a contradiction now.
1) As per technical limitation: we need to launch the VM on the dest host before we can copy the PMEM data to the dest host's PMEM device.
2) As per original intention from the use case: we want to launch the VM with consistent data including the content of the PMEM. 

These two things are not fulfilled by the current proposal. :/ 

So I think we need to do a bit more complicated solution. 

After the libvirt driver on the dest host generated the domain config (get_guest_config), but before it launched the domain (_create_guest) we initiate the PMEM data transfer from the source to the dest. As this logic runs on the dest compute this might need to happen in a way that the dest compute ssh back to the source to copy the data. To do that the dest compute needs to know what is the source compute, and what is the PMEM device to copy from. You have to check if these data is available on the dest. Also this solution probably needs to be parallelized with the vif plug handling that also happens during this time.

Alternatively we can treat the PMEM data as disk. 
1) on the source compute copy the PMEM data from the device to the instance directory
2) migrate the data along with the instance disks (if needed. On shared storage it is not needed)
3) on the dest compute during _create_guest, copy the PMEM content from the instance dir to the device.

The second solution needs more disk space but simplifies the logic of getting the PMEM data to the dest host.

.zuul.yaml.message: Any reason not to make these four options default, too?
I will take a look at each one of those
In case these options are made default, please consider implications outside Zuul CI. In my local lab, the deployment failed and I had to manually set PUBLIC_NETWORK_GATEWAY.

So, I took a look at each of these options

1) Q_USE_PROVIDERNET_FOR_PUBLIC: This one already defaults to True, so it's safe to just remove it from the zuul file.

2) OVN_DBS_LOG_LEVEL: This one defaults to "info" but, given that DevStack is a developers tool and not a production deployment tool (at least that's how I see it) I don't think that defaulting to "dbg" (a.k.a debug mode) is out of scope. I will make the change.

3) ENABLE_CHASSIS_AS_GW: This option is about letting ML2/OVN where to schedule the gateway router ports. If set to True, means that the node is a candidate for hosting such ports. Most DevStack deployments are single node (all-in-one) so it makes sense to have it to True. For multi-node configuration we would need to set this to False on the compute nodes.

4) OVN_L3_CREATE_PUBLIC_NETWORK: The name of this option is misleading IMHO. This option tells DevStack whether to create an external bridge or not [0]. See, it kinda overlaps with ENABLE_CHASSIS_AS_GW in a way that, if ENABLE_CHASSIS_AS_GW is True, most likely this should also be True. Except for the DVR case where we want to have a external bridge in the compute nodes but we do not want router ports scheduled on to it (we want the router ports on gateway nodes and/or controllers). So I am not convinced I should set it to True here, it seems like an option that could be removed if we have the right checks in [0] (by checking the ENABLE_CHASSIS_AS_GW and a DVR option). Tho it would be a bit out of scope to refactor it as part of this patch and we would need [1] to be merged.

Sorry for the long comment, tl;dr I will change all other options but will keep OVN_L3_CREATE_PUBLIC_NETWORK as-is and refactor it as another work.

Let me know if that's OK for you please.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/devstack/blob/9ee7821e80731dc15f71f4e56233c3295497dd53/lib/neutron-legacy#L478-L486

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/755830

I see this as a pretty severe regression in collecting data about devstack runs. Do you have any plans on working on this other than hoping for Ubuntu to fix it? I'm also not convinced that this is actually the same issue, since afaict we do not suspend test instances.

+1. All devstack-based CI jobs across all OpenStack projects would cease to run dstat which comes very handy when troubleshooting issues. Although, dstat development has been terminated. Is there a replacement tool proposed?

Thanks Carlos, Dr. Jens.

Unfortunately dstat is still broken: https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_033/791720/1/check/neutron-ovn-tempest-slow/033255f/controller/logs/screen-dstat.txt

This bug in particular has been open for quite some time [0] but it hasn't been fixed and probably never will because as Carlos mentioned dstat is no longer maintained.

I am not entirely sure how to proceed here other than disabling this service temporarily until we find an alternative service for collecting these stats.

I took the initiative to look at some alternatives, there's a direct fork from dstat called "dool" [1] but I am not sure it's being maintained either, the last commit seems quite old even tho there's nothing in the README indicating that the project is no longer maintained.

Another alternative I found is a project called "glances" [2] this looks promising and seems to be well maintained. I have no experience using it but it's something I can look at implementing in DevStack.

That all said, is disabling dstat a blocker here or could we for the sake of this Neutron effort have it temporarily disabled ? 

[0] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/dstat/+bug/1866619
[1] https://github.com/scottchiefbaker/dool
[2] https://github.com/nicolargo/glances

FYI, Lucas is testing the re-enablement of dstat in the multinode OVN jobs
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/791720

Good news! It seems like the pcp-dstat version does work: https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_6f2/791720/3/check/neutron-ovn-tempest-slow/6f25761/controller/logs/screen-dstat.txt

The DevStack patc is https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/791749. And the test patch is https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/791720

With my upstream hat on, I'd be hesitant to disabling dstat (and without an alternative to it) to accommodate a change to the default Neutron ML2 backend driver. Most non-Neutron projects do not care for what the network backend is, and their CI jobs would stop running dstat.

Controversially, there seems to exist a "successor", "next-generation" to dstat: pcp-dstat [1][2] (yes, the very same one that led dstat maintainers to archive the project). This tool seems to be somewhat a direct replacement and is packaged in most distributions [3].

[2] https://pcp.io/

lib/neutron_plugins/ovn_agent.message: It feels kind of odd to keep this in neutron ... why is installing OVS a thing done here, but the compilation functions for OVS something kept in neutron?

This is legacy because this "ovs" module always existed in Neutron AFAICT and we just reuse it because OVN depends on OVS (not long ago, both projects were part of the same repository so compiling OVS also compiled OVN).

That said, I think we could move the module to DevStack itself. I would need to consult with the Neutron folks about it but I don't see it as a problem.

For now, what this patch does is to only load it if we are actually telling DevStack to compile OVS/OVN from source. By default (and the reason why ensure-devstack does not fail anymore) we install OVS and OVN from the host OS packages.

Should this be enough for this patch ? I can work on moving this module "ovs" module to DevStack on a separated patch.

nova/utils.py.message:
I'm not sure I get the point of the change to stash the image.id in the sysmeta. It seems like what you have here should pretty much always work, and if we did that, we'd have image_meta include id when we pass it to hardware.

Is there some reason instance.image_ref gets lost when it wouldn't be lost in sysmeta? Are you proposing that we (eventually) drop the image_ref column too?

Yeah this is all ground work for resolving bug #1928063 and likely a slew of other issues where we've assumed the image_meta dict being passed around is fully populated when it is in fact only partially populated from instance.system_metadata.

We could change *all* of the places where we assume we have access to things like image_meta.name etc to instance.image_ref but that would cause lots of churn when we could just stash it in system_metadata for new instances and quickly add it in to image_meta for existing instances.

'rados_cluster' recovery backend is designed for active/active ganesha server configuration [1]. Since we're continuing to run ganesha in active/passive HA configuration we should stick to 'rados_kv' recovery backend. The other recovery backend designed for active/passive configuration is 'rados_ng'[2], which is more resilient than 'rados_kv'. We can check whether switching from 'rados_kv' to 'rados_ng' doesn't pose any upgrade issues.

[1] https://github.com/nfs-ganesha/nfs-ganesha/blob/V3-stable/src/config_samples/ceph.conf#L47

ansible/roles/monasca/tasks/bootstrap.ym.message: This change of the whole paragraph shows the evolution of a man. 😉
Is there a risk of losing data we want to keep here?

This task is really about cleaning up topics which are no longer in use, because a service that uses them has been disabled. It's intended to be triggered via a patch, rather than by a user manually tweaking topic configuration. Since the topics contain only transient data, I don't think there is much to worry about, although you could of course shoot yourself in the foot if you really wanted to.

An example might be disabling the alerting pipeline, and removing all associated topics. Sure, you might loose some imminent alerts if you disabled the pipeline, but then you'd disabled the pipeline anyway, and likely wouldn't care about those alerts if you later re-enabled it.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
im not sure this statement is true.

its in direct contodciton to the logic we have applied in nova
for chosing between writeback, none and writetrough
https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b9dc86d8d6

kasyap has look at the detail of how the cache mdoes work several times
i think he should review this change.

Hi,

"Writeback should never be used" is completely incorrect.

- "writethrough" is slow and is _not_ recommended by QEMU Block Layer maintainers in general, as the "write" performance is slow with it.

- when "none" is not available; then "writeback" is the most-recommended.  (Please see the documentation here: https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b9dc86d8d6)

- Ceph upstream recommends "writeback" when you're using "rbd_cache=true" to avoid data loss:

  [quote]
  If you set rbd_cache=true, you must set cache=writeback or risk 
  data loss. Without cache=writeback, QEMU will not send flush 
  requests to librbd. If QEMU exits uncleanly in this 
  configuration, file systems on top of rbd can be corrupted.
  [/quote]

We also note this in Nova's cache modes documentation (see nova/conf/libvirt.py)

[1] https://docs.ceph.com/en/latest/rbd/qemu-rbd/
Done

thank you, that's a lot of feedback!
I'll keep the default then

> Hi,
> 
> "Writeback should never be used" is completely incorrect.
> 
> - "writethrough" is slow and is _not_ recommended by QEMU Block Layer maintainers in general, as the "write" performance is slow with it.

I've recommended writethrough downstream in the InstanceHA usecase where the host compute can be power fenced to ensure data isn't cached. That's pretty much the only use case I can think of where writethrough or directsync would be useful with rbd, otherwise I agree that the default should remain as writeback.

> - when "none" is not available; then "writeback" is the most-recommended.  (Please see the documentation here: https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b9dc86d8d6)
> 
> - Ceph upstream recommends "writeback" when you're using "rbd_cache=true" to avoid data loss:
> 
>   [quote]
>   If you set rbd_cache=true, you must set cache=writeback or risk 
>   data loss. Without cache=writeback, QEMU will not send flush 
>   requests to librbd. If QEMU exits uncleanly in this 
>   configuration, file systems on top of rbd can be corrupted.
>   [/quote]

It's worth highlighting that rbd_cache=true here refers to an old QEMU command line -drive argument and this overrides anything set in ceph.conf:

https://docs.ceph.com/en/latest/rbd/qemu-rbd/#qemu-cache-options

> QEMU’s cache settings override Ceph’s cache settings (including 
> settings that are explicitly set in the Ceph configuration file).
